datasetContactAffiliation.value: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

dsDescriptionValue.value:
AssetsAfrica, implemented from 2004 to 2008, was a demonstration and research initiative designed to test asset building innovations and their impact on household asset accumulation and well-being in rural Africa. The goal was to help build a knowledge base to inform future programs and policies to promote savings and accumulation of productive assets in sub-Saharan Africa. AssetsAfrica was conducted by researchers at the Global Social Development Innovations, in partnership with the Center for Social Development (CSD) at Washington University in St. Louis and Build Africa Uganda.

AssetsAfrica used a nonequivalent groups design with pre and posttest. The study used purposive sampling. Half of the sample households were assigned to the treatment condition and the other half to the comparison condition. Baseline data were collected in August 2005 and a follow-up survey was conducted in September 2006. Data on participants’ savings and withdrawal patterns were tracked and collated using an account monitoring software called MISIDA.

Participants in the treatment group received (1) training in financial management and asset building, and (2) individual bank accounts with the Masindi branch of Stanbic Bank. Participants were expected to save into their accounts for at least six months before they were eligible for a match of 1:1. A household could receive a maximum matched fund of $285. After they reached their savings target and were matched, participants bought their desired assets (e.g., livestock, means of transport, house, land for agricultural use, and tools/equipment for small business start-ups), with the guidance of Build Africa Uganda and CSD.

See publication: Chowa, G., Masa, R., & Sherraden, M. (2012). Wealth effects of an asset building intervention among rural households in sub-Saharan Africa. Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research, 3(4), 329-345

files.description: The baseline and follow-up data included a sample of 445 households in 57 communities from 2 sub-counties in Masindi District, Uganda. The survey data include items on civic and community engagement, household relationships, financial security, social support, household assets, and financial capability.
files.label: AssetsAfrica Baseline and Follow-up Survey Data

files.description: This questionnaire includes items pertaining to civic and community engagement, household relationships, financial well-being, social source of support, asset ownership, savings performance, and money management behaviors.

files.description: This publication examines the effects of AssetsAfrica on financial and productive assets. Research design and intervention features of the project are also described in this publication.
files.label: Wealth Effects of AssetsAfrica
